thread.title: Despite the hopes, cholesterol drugs don't delay progression of prostate cancer
thread.title_full: Despite the hopes, cholesterol drugs don't delay progression of prostate cancer | afr.com

author: Jill Margo
title: Despite the hopes, cholesterol drugs don't delay progression of prostate cancer
text:
Hopes dashed: statins do not stop the progression of prostate cancer. iStock Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Jill Margo There has been lots of talk about statins as the new wonder drug.
It has been suggested this group of cholesterol-lowering medications has many benefits, including anti-cancer properties.
Now a study has shown statins do not lower the risk of dying from prostate cancer.
Researchers from the University of California San Francisco studied 4000 men diagnosed with localised prostate cancer between 1992 and 2008.
Of them, 685 were using statins at the time of their cancer diagnosis. Some 242 went on to die from their cancer.
Researchers found no statistically significant association between post-diagnosis current use of statins or duration of statin use and lethal prostate cancer.
Writing in the journal Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention , they concluded that, in contrast to early suggestions of a beneficial relationship, their results provide little support for the hypothesis that statin use after diagnosis offers benefits against progression to lethal disease.
